segments.text: Do you think the bombing raids and the bombing campaign at LBJ placed into effect was as effective as Nixon's role?
I think to an extent it was.
I think any time you can hit a military target and you can cause any kind of reaction from the military, whether... You know, the ideal situation in any war is to wound everybody, not kill them.
because it takes three or four people to take care of every wounded guy.
So that way you just, you know, if they don't take care of their wounded, then they die.
So then it's their fault and you put the monkey on their back.
So it's better to, you know, if you really want to overcome them quick, wound everybody and don't kill anybody.
Then they've got to take care of each other.
The thing about the bombing is that picture an American ship, a civilian ship,

unloading military cargo in Bremenhaven, and the Germans are fighting the Russians, and nobody else is involved, do you think that the Russians will leave that ship alone, or will they try to sink it in Bremenhaven?
Now, that brings to mind that there were Russian, Cuban, Liberian shipping that got through all the minefields and stuff,
and got into the harbor in Hanoi, and they unloaded military goods, why weren't they all considered targets?
Why weren't they sunk in the harbors?
To me, that's one of the best military targets in the world.
And we would not even fire at those ships, because politically, we didn't want to cut our throats around the world and hurt anybody's feelings.
That's the problem with the American people.
You know, we're already considered ugly Americans.
So when you do something, you know, and I'm losing track of where I want to go, but the thing that I want to say is that you've got to fight fire with fire.
Otherwise, the biggest guy on the block is going to rule, and he may be the dumbest sucker in the world, and he may be sadistic and everything else, but if you don't take out this guy,
then he's going to run the block, and he's going to run your family, and he's going to dictate what you can do in your home.
And that's the way I look at countries.
If everybody doesn't have to agree with America, I don't expect them to.
It would be a screwed-up world if they did.
And America's not always right in our policies, and I'll be the first one to say that.
But basically, around the world, with the rights that we have for people in our own country, and we try to get those rights into other country systems.
And unless you get out of the country and see what some of these other countries look like, you won't understand what I'm talking about.
But you've got to go around and see what happens in other countries before you can start talking about the United States.
The United States, as bad as it may be for some people, is still the best country in the world to live in.
It really is.
And I've been to France and Europe and all over Southeast Asia, and I'm telling you now,
that the United States is the best country in the world to live in.
You don't go home at night after 6 o'clock and shut all your lights out and crawl into a bunker under your kitchen.
A lot of people still do that in Southeast Asia because they're still fighting over there.
You don't have to worry about terrorism that much right now in the United States.
They worry about it all over Europe.
How do you feel about those who protested, but protested by leaving the country and going to Canada and coming back?
There were a lot of ways to protest the actions in South Vietnam.
You could have legally stayed in this country and rested yourself as a conscientious objector.
And you could have stayed right here.
And then you would have had to face your peer group
and the relations next door that had sons and daughters in South Vietnam.
They copped out then, and they're going to cop out again whenever it happens.
They're never going to be able to face a major decision in their life.
I don't think they should have been allowed to come back to this country.
I think they're all a bunch of cowards.
And I'm not saying just because they didn't go fight in South Vietnam.
I'm saying that they'll never stand up
for the Declaration of Independence.
They'll never stand up for the flag of this country.
They wouldn't do it then, and they never will.
I wouldn't care if you declared a World War III.
These kind of people you're going to have all the time, regardless.
It don't make any difference.
You're going to have a certain few that are going to run away from everything.
We've got to remember also that this is not the first time that people have ran off
and going to Canada.
They did it during the Korean War.
They got amnesty when they came back then.
And I wish they all had to wear a sign or they had a tattoo on their forehead.
I ran away.
I wasn't there, okay?
There was other ways to serve your country.
You could have joined the National Guard.
You could have joined the Reserves.
You could have went to Europe.
You could have been a medic or a doctor or a nurse.
You didn't have to really participate in the fighting.
Okay?
There was just other ways to do it and still remain an American.
As far as I'm concerned, they all should have lost their citizenship.
And they should be still living in Canada where they were freezing their tails off instead of coming back here after they got their good educations and stuff and getting good jobs.
I don't have any sympathy for them.
And I don't want to meet them, don't want to shake their hands, and don't want to talk to them, and certainly don't even want to be in the same room with them.
Well, how do you feel about those who were conscientious objectors, but they burned their draft cards and protested on campuses and stuff like that?
Do you have the same attitude towards them?
Well, you know, burning your draft card doesn't prevent you from getting drafted.
That's true.

And for the ones that seriously knew what they were doing and stood up and made a stand in front of everybody here at home, you know, and faced that here at home, I can accept that a lot more than I can them going away from Camden just out of sight, out of mind, and then after it's all over coming back.
There were a lot of guys that went to South Vietnam that didn't want to go.
There were a lot of guys that were kind and gentle and had no business being over there.
There were a lot of them that just couldn't adapt, and a lot of them are still there.
There was 50-something thousand guys killed in South Vietnam, and I doubt if any one of them,
wanted to bleed and die in a foreign country.
You know, you're just not going to find the guy that's going to raise his hand and volunteer and say, hey, I'll bleed and die in South Vietnam.
Now, they all went over and tried to do a service for their country that they thought was right.
Because like I say, they wanted to fight communism there instead of Texas or Oklahoma or Louisiana or someplace like that.
Okay, what you want to know is about guys going native.
And I mentioned to you before that we had Marine contact teams that would go out into the villages during harvest and stuff like that and help the regional forces protect the village.
And as far as that taking place, those were good ideas because...
It was a show of force from the Americans for the Arvins, or for the South Vietnamese government, to help protect the villages while they harvested their crops and protect them from the V.C.
so they could have a school or so that they could even have a church.
And they could, if they wanted to, worship in that church.
And it helped set up irrigation systems and build buildings and new schools and stuff like that.
But as far as guys going completely native and wearing black pajamas and doing things like that, I was never in a position to see things like that.
I know that...
If you were in a...
I just never saw that.
I guess guys back in the big firebases and stuff like that would wear black pajamas around in the evening because they were comfortable and you didn't have to wear your uniform 24 hours a day.
I wasn't in a position to see that.
I had my uniform on 24 hours a day.
And if that was something that was happening, I don't think it was...
I don't think it was very much of it.

There was a lot of guys that would go into a village and live in a hooch, you know, five or six guys, and these were the guys that stayed with that village for maybe two or three weeks, and then they'd leave and another five guys would come in.
And this was just during harvest times and stuff like that to really help them get set up and have their own defensive system as far as the...
what they call the rough puffs or the popular forces were concerned, teach them just so much stuff.
But most of that kind of stuff was done by advisors until you got way out in the woods someplace.
And if there was a local fire base or something like that and they had asked for help, then we'd send four or five guys out for a while.
But to go completely native was a dangerous thing to do because if you partied with them, familiarity breeds contempt.
Now that's a wide statement, but for a military man, that's so much more true than for anybody else, I think.
In ranks and out of ranks.
They were sent out there to do a job, and if they became that familiar and started dressing like the people and acting like the people...
then they were no longer part of the U.S. military forces.
They were just one of the guys, and they were there to be part of the military forces.
Does that answer your question about going native?
Yes, sir.
In your statement about what you just said about going into the villages and mostly there was advisors, was this a type of pacification program?
Well, every military district had military advisors.
There were so many ARVN units in these districts.
So each Arvin unit had a military advisor, a U.S. military advisor.
I think it only went down to battalion level.
I'm not sure because I was never in an advisory group.
But I know that most Arvin units in South Vietnam, whether it was a straight-legged unit, ranger, airborne, it didn't make any difference.
Armin Cav, they had guys that specialized.
Like if it was an Armin Cav unit, then they had Armin Cav sergeants and officers, American officers and enlisted men
that were advisors for that armored unit.
During LBJ's term, what did you see or do you think that the Gulf of Tonkin incident allowed him to escalate without asking Congress to declare war?
Frankly, I didn't see anything.
You know, if you've been shot at a few times,
A couple little old gunboats coming out and taking on a destroyer or frigate is pretty damn stupid.
And for us to escalate in South Vietnam because a U.S. ship was fired on by a PT boat, give me a break.
You know, it's like shooting at a guy armed with an automatic weapon with a .22 pistol.
It's pretty stupid.
It was an excuse.
A real flimsy excuse.
But if that's what they wanted it for, it got the job done.
How did you see McCarthyism and the Red Scare affect Vietnam?
Well, I've got to go back to...
The thing that you're trained for in the military nowadays is not so much the Russians, but it's...

It's basic doctrine, and it's geared towards terrorism, counterinsurgency, and I guess if you had to, you could say that if we're ever going to fight anybody, you always pick the guy that you train for.
All your training is geared towards the guy that you think one of these days you're going to fight.
For us, after the Germans, there was nobody left around to really pick on the United States except Russia.
They were big enough and armed well enough to harass us or pick on us, if you want to say that.
I know for a fact that in talking to some of my German friends that right after the war was over, they all buried their weapons.
They didn't turn them in.
They buried them with ammunition and everything because they just knew that the United States was going to ask them to help fight the Russians.
And I ask him why, and he says, well, everybody knows the Russians are bad people.
You know?
And are they?
I've only met two in my life, and they were officers, and...
Never said much to them.
I was a master sergeant, and they were a colonel and a line general.
So what am I going to say?
And I would think that the Russian people are basically like the American people.
They want to be happy.
They want to eat food.
They want to have clothes and shelter.
And they want to be left alone to enjoy their lives.
So who am I to say that the Russians are bad?
I've never met any.
But the military trains us for 20 years.
They train me to fight the Russians because those are the guys that can cause the most problems for us.
And I'm not saying that we'll ever fight the Russians, but we prepare for what we consider to be the worst.
That's the way the military training goes.
But I don't think we'll ever fight Russia.
I don't think we'll be stupid enough to fight Russia.
And I certainly don't think Russia is stupid enough to fight us.
I really don't.
There may be some isolated incidents
you know, small fire fights or stuff like the Russians and the Chinese have got going along their borders right now.
I just don't see the United States getting involved in a major war with a major country.
I see us trying to do things in Nicaragua, in South America, to protect our own fronts.
You know, where are we going with all this stuff?
If we fight anything else but a conventional war, everybody's a loser.
It doesn't make any difference whose side you're on.
If it doesn't stay conventional and some idiot like Gaddafi gets an atomic weapon and pushes the button, everybody loses.
Do you see in Nicaragua right now any correlations between Vietnam
Do you see us, with our advisors, as it started out in Vietnam, do you see us maybe escalating?
Or do you think, due to the Russians' involvement in Afghanistan and such a problem they're having, that nothing will ever come of it, that they'll get tired of fighting eventually?
I think the most that we'll ever do in South America, if the situation doesn't change in South America...
One of these days, because it's so close to us, the United States is going to have a major problem in South America.
And this may cause some hairs to be raised in your class, but if we don't influence the situations on borders that are directly related to our own country,
then you're going to have a problem.
The relationship between us and Canada is leveling out.
There's more give and take now, and there will be between now and 1992.
Tariffs will be lifted.
Free enterprise is going to take over.
But the people in South America can't relate to that.
All they're trying to do is just find enough food
so they can live one more day.
And until you can make situations better for people like that, then you're going to have a problem, because they don't care if they live or die.
And if they can die for a cause that they never had before, hey, that's great.
And I think the ideal for South America is special forces.
And guerrilla-trained units, you're not going to be able to go in there with conventional units, except get a lot of people killed.
You're going to have to go down there and fight those people the same way that they fight.
And I don't think... And the only way to do that is with money.
You're going to have to pour money after money after money into the country.
But you've got to be there to see how the money's spent.
and you've got to control it until they're capable of controlling it themselves.
And I don't see anybody down there right now that's capable of controlling it.
They're doing it with force and arms, and they're doing it with Russian weapons and communist bloc advisors.
So why are they there?
Why did we allow missiles for so long into Cuba?
Why do we even allow Fidel Castro to exist?
Is he not a threat to the United States in the way that we live, in the things that we have?
You don't think for a minute if he could get away with it that he wouldn't come up here and take everything that we had?
So where do you stop these people and people like him?
Or do you just turn the other cheek?
and let them to continue to exist and get stronger and stronger and stronger until you have to do something with your military service.
I don't have all the answers.
A lot of people say that it's very simple to put on a uniform and just obey your orders.
It's not.
Because the higher you go in the military structure, the more difficult your life becomes.
Because now you're making decisions for everybody else below you.
And sometimes that's not easy.
But I think special forces, ranger-type units can go into South America, and it's not all going to be done at a conference table, okay?
But if you can exert enough pressure against the opposing forces where they have to sit down and talk to you,
as an equal.
And it's leveled out enough to where they can't say one thing and you've got to do it because they can overpower you.
It all has to be equal.
And you've got to force them to the table.
You don't have to force your way of life on them, but you have to make it where the people can make a decision and not just two or three hundred of those people because they've got the guns.
You've got to take the guns away from them so everybody's equal and they can all make a decision.
And if the country has an election and it's not rigged or anything, and that's what the people want, then get the hell out of it and let them have it.
Unless it's so close to you that it's going to hurt your own boards.
I'm rambling.
In 1957, had, in 56, excuse me, had
Vietnam and allowed to hold the elections and they had elected Ho Chi Minh, should we have backed out then?
I think so.
I don't know of anybody, enemy or foe, that did not hold Ho Chi Minh in high regard.
I think any time
you take a man of the people and he rises to such heights, then you've got to respect this individual for what he's done and what he's done for his country.
The greatest thing that could have happened was that Ho Chi Minh in 1957 could have been elected by the people, all the people.
Okay?
And then we could have laid down our weapons, and we couldn't have invaded Cambodia or Laos or anything else like that.

They could have had a protectionary force to guard their borders, and they could have started dealing and wheeling with everybody else in the world, you know, exporting their rice and coconuts and whatever else it is that they had to export and get people in.
You know, one of the greatest resort areas in the world
would be the China Beach in South Vietnam.
It would make Acapulco and Miami look sick.
The water's green, emerald green.
The beaches were white-sanded.
The weather was terrific.
And if you didn't want to lay on the beach and get a suntan, you could hunt tigers up in the mountains.
But South Vietnam is a beautiful country, and they have a lot to offer people.
I thought the country was beautiful.
But I think there's a lot of times you got to stand back and you got to let things happen.
I think if they would have had an opportunity to be free for a while and not have anybody's thumb pressed on them like the French, then they would have had an opportunity to do something.
Why do you think the elections were not held?
Why do you think the Geneva Accord was not followed?
Because I don't think everybody got the word to all the people in South Vietnam and North Vietnam.

I think they reached the major educated people in the cities, but I don't think there was a real continuous effort to get out there in the villages where all the work was being done and the food was being raised to talk to that villager to get them in to vote
So everyone had an opportunity.
It's not like the United States.
There wasn't any radio and TV and millions of dollars spent on, hey, I'm the best guy, and this guy's going to do this to you, but I'll do this for you.
Their elections aren't like that.
And I don't think there was a major effort to get all the people involved.
And I think that's the same way in South America.
As far as I know, we're probably one of the very few countries that do that.
Look at France.
Look what de Gaulle did in France.
Look what Hitler did in Germany.
Most of the German people at that time thought Hitler was a god.
And there's a lot of them that still do.
Do you think that maybe our allies, our commitment to our Western allies, such as Britain and France, helped not hold the elections because France wanted to come back in and have Vietnam as a colony?

I think so, and I can understand why France wanted South Vietnam as a colony, because they had put so much money in it, they had all those plantations over there, there was a lot of rich people involved in those decisions that influenced what the government in France wanted.
You know, let me ask you a question, okay?
Who runs the United States?
Is it the government, by the people, for the people?
Or is it big business?
I would say to an extent big business.
So would I.
And I think big business, regardless of what country you're in, certainly has an awful lot to do with how the government makes their decisions.
And I think that that's real true right here in the United States.

If we did what you suggested with the Rangers and the Special Forces, like Kennedy was doing in Vietnam and someone tried to escalate, do you think they would look back and study Vietnam and Korea and say, wait a minute,
Wait a minute, do you think that we're that aware and enough study is being done about Vietnam to see the implications that it has?
Julie, I think everybody has looked at Vietnam for so long, but I want to make a real quick comment here.
The wheel revolves, okay?
It's going to come around again.
It may be South America.
It may be back in Vietnam.
It may be in Cambodia.
But somebody is going to make a wrong decision, and they'll commit troops someplace where there really wasn't a need for it.
If we would have stayed out of South Vietnam and went to Special Forces,

do their jobs and just had advisors and special forces people there and fought the enemy the way they fought us and trained the South Vietnamese people were there wasn't any black market or the money was going to the right people instead of being used wrong you know then there would have been a ceasefire there would have been a South Vietnam and a North Vietnam they would have always argued
Or maybe it could be all one South Vietnam right now.
It could be a total Vietnam.
But there would still be a Saigon, and there'd still be a Hanoi.
But there would be one government.
I don't know.
And I'm not advocating special forces.
But before you commit an army, you've got to recon the area.
And the special forces...

are trained to help people help themselves and to me if you're going to do anything that above all has to be done first and if special forces is the answer for that then commit to special forces and some advisors and then stop it and that way you're not over committed and if you decide later or your uh your congress decides later
that we've made a mistake, then you haven't overcommitted.
And you can pull those people out of there.
Okay?
Okay, you said a lot of people had studied Vietnam and looked at Vietnam.
Do you think that shows through the movies that have come out, especially during this decade?
And how do you feel about those movies and films that have come out?
Well...
My dad is a veteran of our country's uniforms.
He spent 10 years in the Marine Corps and he fought in the South Pacific for four and a half years until he was wounded.
And then he spent the rest of the time in the Air Force.
And he didn't watch any war movies.
The first movie I saw about South Vietnam to include John Wayne's Green Beret movie was last year.
I wouldn't watch war movies either.
But I got so hung up about what the American people thought about GIs and what our actions were and how we could condone such savagery.

that I went and got every one of these movies, Platoon, Hamburger Hill, The Boys in Company C, Green Berets, and out of all of them, I'd have to say that the one that I thought that best depicted, I'll get a lot of comments from this if everybody hears this tape, was the Green Berets.
And it wasn't a big, could be because it had John Wayne in it, too.
He's my favorite guy.
Always has been.
Nobody liked the Duke.
But there was a lot of, you know, when you take a movie, like, let's take Platoon, for instance.
Everybody says, well, that's, God, that's it.
That's just the way the guys were in South Vietnam.
Well, to an extent, it is.
I spent two years in South Vietnam and fought with a lot of different units and not once did I see a group of guys rape a bunch of kids.
Never, ever did I see that or hear of it.
Shooting innocent villagers intentionally, I never saw.
Maybe I was different.
I certainly wasn't blind.
I think I saw everything that could conceivably happen as far as warfare goes in those two years.
But I've known a lot of sergeants that would have shot those men right there on the spot that was raping those little girls.
I can give you three.
B.J.
Babbage, Sergeant Thompson, and Bob Mathis.
We would have shot them.
And then face the consequences for it later.
One of the most savage people on earth is an American soldier.
Given the certain surroundings and what's going on.
You know, burning villages down.
There was a lot of story in...
The platoon story took about seven or major instances that took place in South Vietnam, and threw them all together, okay?
And, well, for the weapons, for instance, the mini M16 that the sergeants carried.
Oh, geez, give me a break.
It didn't even hit the country until late 69, and the date on the movie was 67, along the Cambodian border with the 25th Entry Division.
Uh...
I don't know.
There was a lot of things in the movie that depicted the firefights.
The ambush was good.
The country was good.
All those showed Vietnam.
I just cannot see...
The thing about the rape and shooting innocent civilians, I don't think that happened.
And I think when people see, well, it happened, okay, with maybe two or three units, and it happened even with the unit that I was in, the 11th Infantry Brigade.
But you had one or two guys that just, they lost it.
You know, they just lost control.
But people see that on film, and they don't show all the instances leading up to it.
And there were circumstances and situations that made those guys lose it.
You know, Cali went from a 44-man platoon down to about 20 guys in about three months due to booby traps and sniper fire and things like that.
And they had been trying to get into my life,
for months and couldn't do it because of the firepower that was still in there.
And if they went in there to try to get the VC or the NVA out, at least they didn't set back offshore and hit it with naval gunfire or put a B-52 strike on the village.
You know?
And that was somebody's answer.
Let's do that.
That way we won't get anybody hurt.
Because every time we ever tried to go into my life, we got people hurt.
Kelly knew that, and so did the guys that were with him.
But they lost it for a few minutes.
You know?
I don't know.
Movies are movies, Julie.
There's not very much...

about a war movie I mean you can say oh gee look at that and see how they did this and everything but the only guys or the only people that really appreciate those war movies are the guys that were there because they can relate to everything that happened in those movies or basically as far as the fighting is concerned
And if you've never been there, then you can't relate to it.
To you, it's just a movie.
But for a lot of guys that wore uniforms, it's reliving an experience.
And that's the difference.
Civilians can walk out of those movies and say, boy, I'm glad I wasn't there.
Gee, I'm glad that wasn't me.
Oh, that's not true.
And yeah, it is.
And for military guys, all it does is bring back bad memories.
Because nobody likes getting shot or being shot at.
Even the police can attest to that.
How do you see South Vietnam today?
and what they're trying to do and the fact that they've opened it up and start let Americans come back to Vietnam and what's going on in Cambodia and Laos.
Did you ever see the movie Killing Fields?
Parts of it.
If that film hadn't been shown in your class,
That would be a good one to show everybody.
I don't hold any grudges against the South Vietnamese or North Vietnamese people.
One day I'd like to go back over there and just have the freedom to walk around some of the places that I've been and not worry about hitting a booby trap or getting shot.
Because like I said before, it was a beautiful country.
I'd go back for a visit.
Certainly wouldn't want to go back over there and fight anymore.
And I'd even like to sit down and talk to some of the guys that I fought against.
Cambodia and Laos, I don't know.
I'm glad that the South Vietnamese, or excuse me, I'm glad that the Vietnamese people
are finally going to settle this thing as far as the MIAs are concerned.
If they are, there's going to be some guys that you're never going to find.
And that said, there's a lot of those people that don't want to be found.
You notice there's a difference between POWs and MIAs.
There were even several soldiers in some of the areas that I was in that fought for the North Vietnamese Army.
And they were XGIs.
They just went from one side to the other.
And that's not uncommon.
That happens in any war.
Hey, I'm on the wrong side.
Jump over to the other side.
Unless Vietnam and these
What are we going to call them?
Undeveloped countries.
Their culture goes back 2,000 years, but they're undeveloped, okay?
I guess.
Unless they can get out and participate in everything that's going on in this world and contribute to it and feed their people, then there's going to be another South Vietnam.
And that would be sad.
So where do you draw the line?
Do you send them the money and start helping them, giving them loans?
I don't have the answers for that kind of thing.
But it would seem to me that it would be better to give them a loan than give them an infantry battalion.
At least if you lose your money, you don't lose any lives.
And I think that's the final answer, is not to lose any more lives.
Because I, for one, would like to stay here and raise my kids and enjoy my family.
And I don't think there's anybody else that doesn't want the same things.
It's too bad you can't get everybody around the round table from all these countries and sit down and help each other out.
That won't always work.
It's not always the answer.
Somebody's got to fire the first round and be an idiot.
You know, they tell you that there's nothing that happens in this world that you can't discuss and sit down and work out.
That may be true if that's what everybody wants to do.
But there's always somebody that don't want to talk.
They'd rather fight because that's easier.
And they think that's a faster solution than talking.
Okay, yeah, it took them a year and a half to figure out what kind of table they wanted at the Paris Peace Talks.
What for?
Who cares what kind of table it is as long as we sit down and start talking?
Can you imagine how many guys died in a year and a half because them idiots couldn't figure out what kind of table they wanted?
Nobody wins in a war.
It's a sad situation.
Is there one particular topic or one question or a few questions that you'd like to make comments about that I haven't asked you?
I guess even after eight years of wearing a uniform, being away from the military eight years after doing 20 years in the military,
I would like somebody like LBJ to sit down and explain to me why I was there.
Now, I can basically defend why I was there myself, but I certainly don't have all the answers about Vietnam.
And I've read a lot of books, and I've tried to find answers.
I don't think anybody knows.
I really don't.
I think there was a lot of money made in Vietnam.
I think it was bad for the country that Vietnam happened.
I don't regret my service to my country.
And I certainly don't regret wearing my uniform for 20 years in the service of my country.
And the two years that I did in South Vietnam, I did in an honorable, soldierly way.
I did not condone or commit any war crimes.
I tried to keep people alive.
And I tried to do a job that I thought my country wanted done.
And by my country, I mean my leaders.
I'm not saying they were always right, but they were my leaders.
So I did my duty.
And I think that as long as you have men in uniform,
They're there for the service of the country.
And when you have men in uniform that rule the country, then that's wrong.
So, if the soldiers were in South Vietnam, who's at fault?
The government?
Or the poor slob wearing the uniform?
You know, there's a lot of military men that will tell you that it's really unfortunate that we didn't have our seven days of May.
But it's our system.
And we may not like it sometimes, but it's still the best one going.
And until somebody comes up with the one better, I'll still fight for the one I got.
And it may tick off some of the civilians and you may have guys run to Canada again.
But if my country ever needs me again, I'll go.
Because that's what my country needs.
Not my needs, but what my wants are.
But what the country needs.
And if they need me, then I'll go.
And I guess my brother would go and my father, he's 70 years old, and he would want to go too.

And I just, you know, I'll make one last statement that this country would not be where it is today and would not even continue to exist as we know it if it wasn't for men like my brother and my father and myself.
Veterans.
Hello.
